channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: IHT Special: Resentment Grows Against Syrian Refugees in Jordan
item.description: As refugees continue to flow across the border, Jordanians are suffering economically.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Israel Moves to End Gender Segregation in Public Spaces
item.description: The attorney general called on public agencies “to act fast, efficiently and decisively” on sweeping new rules after years of legal battles over the treatment of women.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Pakistan's Historic Elections
item.description: Declan Walsh, the Times’ Islamabad bureau chief, previews the upcoming election on May 11, which promises the first democratic transfer of power from one civilian government to another.

item.title: At War Blog: Celebrating a Wife Who Has Had to Spend Mother’s Day Alone
item.description: A Marine Corps veteran reflects on the sacrifices his wife made in raising their children during his two combat deployments.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ZACHARY BELL
item.media:description: Zachary Bell with his family after his second deployment.

item.title: Yousaf Raza Gilani’s Son Is Kidnapped in Pakistan
item.description: Gunmen kidnapped a son of former Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani, according to media reports, throwing an already violence-ridden election campaign into more tumult.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: People visited the former Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani on Thursday in Multan after one of his sons, Ali Haider Gilani, was abducted.

item.title: Syrian Refugee Crisis Growing
item.description: Having just returned from a visit to refugee camps in Iraq and Turkey, Marc Hanson, a senior advocate for Refugees International, talks to the Times about what he saw on the ground.

item.title: Official Offers Account From Libya of Benghazi Attack
item.description: An official gave a riveting account of the terrorist attack in Libya last Sept. 11 and described its aftermath at a charged Congressional hearing that reflected weighty political stakes.
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE, JEREMY W. PETERS and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gregory Hicks, center, a State Department official, presented on Wednesday the first public testimony from an American official who was in Libya during the siege of the diplomatic compound in Benghazi last Sept. 11.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Mt. Everest Guide Norbu Sherpa
item.description: A veteran high Himalayas guide on how climbing in Nepal has changed in recent years and his life as a Sherpa.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:credit: Percy Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Norbu Sherpa on the Khumbu Glacier near the Everest base camp in Nepal.

item.title: Family Planning Officials Investigate Chinese Film Director
item.description: China’s most celebrated film director, Zhang Yimou, could face a hefty fine if he is found to have fathered more children than allowed by law.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Soccer Coach’s Departure Trumps British News
item.description: The retirement of the Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson, after a quarter-century reign, is the number one talking point in Britain this week and has prompted tributes from the country’s top politicians.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Sir Alex Ferguson at the Manchester United touchline on Sunday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In Malaysia’s Election, a Free Press Was Elusive
item.description: Limits on a free press in Malaysia undercut the nation’s claims to have held a free and fair election, critics say.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Demonstrators attended a rally in protest of Sunday's election result at a stadium outside Kuala Lumpur on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: What They Said: Death of Pakistani Prisoner Sanaullah Ranjay
item.description: Reaction in India and Pakistan to the death of a Pakistani killed in an Indian jail.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR and MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: Sanaullah Ranjay, inside the Kotbhalwal Central Jail in Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir, on May 20, 2011.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Genetics Reveal Europe Is One Big Family
item.description: A new study indicates all Europeans — from Ireland to Turkey — have shared ancestors who were alive just 1,000 years ago. Will a reminder of their common origins help them get on better than they sometimes have in the past?
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside the Reichstag in Berlin this week held a sign reading, "We remember the NSU victims. The problem is racism." The trial of Beate Zschäpe, the surviving member of a neo-Nazi group accused of killing 8 people, and four other defendants began Monday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 9
item.description: Demanding more information about clothing’s origins; fighting to keep local traditions alive in Italy; a “new Louvre” north of Paris draws crowds; and a soccer giant’s retirement shakes the worlds of sports and business.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Michal Czerwonka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Preysman, chief of the online boutique Everlane, at a plant in Vernon, Calif., where its T-shirts and sweatshirts are made.

item.title: Fire at Bangladeshi Factory Kills 8
item.description: The fire late Wednesday at the Tung Hai Sweater Factory in Dhaka, the capital, again raised questions about the safety of garment factories in Bangladesh.
item.category: Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Association
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Boston Bombing Inquiry Looks Closely at Russia Trip
item.description: Officials are investigating reports that Tamerlan Tsarnaev, a suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, may have tried to contact Islamist extremists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Syrian Refugees in Jordan Struggle to Survive
item.description: More than half the 500,000 Syrian refugees in Jordan are under 18. “They can’t see beyond, frankly, the next day,” an aid worker says.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: U.S. Fears Russia May Sell Air Defenses to Syria
item.description: The delivery of the Russian S-300 missile batteries would represent a major qualitative advancement in Syria’s air defenses.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has benefited from the support of Iran and Russia.

item.title: Okinawa Piques Chinese Papers
item.description: Chinese state-run newspapers are questioning Japan’s sovereignty over the island, the latest sign of growing nationalism and territorial ambitions among China’s elite.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: New Fatal Fire at Bangladesh Clothes Maker
item.description: The fire late Wednesday at the Tung Hai Sweater Factory in Dhaka, the national capital, again raises questions about the safety of garment factories in Bangladesh.
item.category: Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Assn
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Bill Would Deny Iran Access to Foreign Exchange Reserves
item.description: A bipartisan group of senators introduced legislation that would deny the Iranian government access to its foreign-exchange reserves in the banks of other countries.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Iran Hostages See Renewed Focus on Their Plight
item.description: After finding their captivity in Iran three decades ago seemingly forgotten, they now see hope in a 17-year battle for compensation.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: The just-released hostages in 1981, at an air base outside Frankfurt, on their way home.

item.title: Claude Guéant, a Sarkozy Ally, at Center of Corruption Allegations
item.description: The scandal involving Claude Guéant, a former interior minister, involves a bank transfer, two Flemish paintings and tens of thousands of dollars in cash payments.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Ex-Aide to Medvedev and Putin Out at Kremlin
item.description: The former adviser, Vladislav Y. Surkov, had coined the phrase “sovereign democracy” to describe the new Russian system, with popular but closely manipulated elections.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Vladislav Y. Surkov, left, with then-prime minister Vladimir V. Putin last year.

item.title: Argument to Overturn Detainee’s Conviction Cites Years in Custody Without a Trial
item.description: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, the only terrorist detainee to be held at the Guantánamo Bay prison and then tried in the civilian court system, is seeking to have his conviction overturned.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
